p: Limited situational awareness can have substantial negative impact. In the case of the pandemic H1N1 flu in 2009, early analyses mistakenly assumed that the epidemic had been only recently introduced, causing substantial overestimates of the basic reproduction ratio [ 6] and case fatality rates [ 7] that suggested a far greater risk to human life than was actually the case, leading to a more resource-intensive response than was necessary [ 8]. The more complex settings typical of livestock and particularly wildlife systems tend to result in the available surveillance data being sparser still for animal diseases [ 9].
